awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Integrating Cybersecurity Education with Cloud Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Cybersecurity has been identified as one of the most serious economic and national security challenges the nation faces.  However, current cybersecurity education has not kept pace with the rapidly changing world of modern computing technologies.  This project will produce curricular materials that will allow instructors to teach cybersecurity as it relates to cloud computing environments.  A set of reusable virtual platforms will be developed, that will be used by a wide audience to effectively learn network and system security in cloud computing.  The curricular materials that will be developed as a result of this project will result in more efficient student learning and engagement, which over time will lead to a better trained and prepared security workforce.   Feedback from students using the materials will allow for the development of more effective teaching methods.

The undergraduate and graduate cybersecurity curriculum will be updated by developing a series of laboratory exercises under the context of cloud environments.   In each laboratory exercise students will be provided with the background knowledge needed to complete the exercise, and then using a reusable framework, students will develop their own code and conduct experiments independently.  Students will be taught how to analyze experimental results and summarize the attack and defense strategies learned from the experiments.  These course materials will allow students to become familiar with the major security and privacy issues in cloud computing, become aware of the latest progress in cloud security research, deepen their understanding of the basic concepts of network and system security, and learn the important programming and system skills via hands-on experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have integrated cybersecurity education with the latest security research activities in cloud computing. In particular, we have enhanced the undergraduate and graduate security curriculum by developing a series of laboratory exercises under the context of cloud computing environments. These specially crafted new course materials have allowed students to be familiar with significant security and privacy issues in cloud computing, and know the latest progress in cloud security research. The exercises have also deepened their understanding of the basic concepts of network and system security, and provided hands-on experiences for them to learn the critical programming and system skills. 


Given the fact that a cloud computing environment is mainly supported by virtualization in data centers, we have completed the development of proposed laboratory exercises centered on virtualization. More specifically, a set of educational laboratories for both undergraduate and graduate student levels have been used in our security courses, allowing students to better understand the security risks of side-channels existing in modern shared computing infrastructures (e.g. data centers, VMs, containers, multi-user operating systems).  

Undergraduate and graduate students have gained practical hands-on experience hardening the computing systems in cloud environments against cyber attack as well as learning the offensive techniques and practices used by their attackers. PI Wang has created a new course “Cloud Computing and Security” (CPEG/ELEG 473/673) to provide a focused environment to enhance these proposed laboratory exercises. And Co-PI Cotton has introduced student access and operation on central hypervisor servers as part of a laboratory to harden windows systems taught since the fall of 2015 in the “System Hardening and Protection” class (CPEG/ELEG 494/694).


From a broader perspective, the University of Delaware’s participation and sponsorship of week-long college and graduate-level cybersecurity camps organized with fellow state educational institutions has led to the spread of educational best practices and techniques both to fellow state educational institutions as well as to the cybersecurity professionals and educators who teach the courses at the camp each year. We have incorporated these exercises as timely cloud topics in short courses at the summer camps and other educational outreach opportunities. 

In total, we have published 10 high quality research papers in conferences and journals under the support of this grant. Six different Ph.D. students have actively participated in the educational tasks outlined in this project over the past three years. The students have not only developed lab exercises, but have also deployed them and conducted preliminary tests. The overall experience has prepared them for solid careers in both academic and industrial research. Three of them have received their Ph.D. degrees at the University of Delaware by the end of 2021.
